intro: Convolvulus sistanicus, commonly known as the Sistan morning glory, is a flowering plant native to arid regions of Iran and Afghanistan. It belongs to the Bindweed family (Convolvulaceae) and is characterized by its climbing habit and trumpet-shaped flowers. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers that open in the morning and close in the afternoon. Its leaves are heart-shaped and covered with fine hairs, and it thrives in dry, sandy soils. It is often found in rocky and semi-desert environments, adapting well to harsh climatic conditions.
